channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: How The New York Times Investigated Videos of ICE Agents Killing Alex Pretti
item.description: Using more than a dozen videos related to the shooting of Alex Pretti, The Times worked to establish what is called ground truth: what happened, how it happened and who might be responsible.
item.dc:creator: Mark Scheffler

item.title: White House Distances Trump From Initial Response to Minnesota Killing
item.description: The departure of Gregory Bovino, whose tactics have drawn sharp criticism, is an indication that officials see Alex Pretti’s killing as a political threat to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: “This has obviously been a very fluid and fast-moving situation throughout the weekend,” Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, said on Monday.

item.title: Winter Storm Debilitates the South, Encasing Cities in Ice and Snow
item.description: The forecasts had predicted that the storm could be among the worst in a generation to hit the region. By Monday, it was clear that is exactly what happened.
item.dc:creator: LaReeca Rucker and Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some storm damage in Nashville on Sunday. Nashville Electric Service said that as many as 230,000 people were without power at the peak, the largest number of simultaneous power outages in the agency’s history.

item.title: Scenes From the Winter Storm
item.description: Images from across much of the United States illuminate snow-covered streets and the storm’s aftermath.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Some visitors to Times Square in Manhattan on Sunday were undeterred by the winter weather.

item.title: How Does Climate Change Affect Winter Storms?
item.description: A warmer atmosphere has the potential to hold more moisture, which can contribute to heavier precipitation in any season, scientists say.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Aristide Economopoulos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Snow falling in Montclair, N.J., on Sunday.

item.title: Winter Storm Linked to at Least 22 Deaths in the US
item.description: The storm deaths were reported in New York, Tennessee, Louisiana, Kansas, Texas, Massachusetts, Arkansas, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Mississippi, Kentucky and New Jersey, and other deaths were under investigation.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Liam Kennedy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Deaths related to the winter storm were reported in multiple states.

item.title: What to Expect for a Cold NYC Commute: Trains, Buses and Rail
item.description: Mass transit is slowly getting back to normal around the city.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
item.media:description: An M.T.A. bus passing Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn on Sunday.

item.title: No Snow Day? In New York City Parks, It Felt Like One.
item.description: Some children skipped remote classes in city schools in favor of activities they felt were more important: sledding and snowball fights.
item.dc:creator: Kaja Andric and Tim Balk
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children and families went sledding in Prospect Park in Brooklyn on Monday.

item.title: After Mamdani Nods to ‘Heated Rivalry,’ Library E-Book Downloads Surge
item.description: As a snowstorm arrived, Mayor Zohran Mamdani reminded New Yorkers that they could access the romance series that inspired the TV show through their public library.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: At a Sunday news conference, Mayor Zohran Mamdani mentioned the New York Public Library’s promotion of “Heated Rivalry,” the romance novel that was adapted into a wildly popular TV show.

item.title: Record Debt in the World’s Richest Nations Threatens Global Growth
item.description: The cost of borrowing is already choking crucial public spending in many developing economies. Now it’s raising broader alarms.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Record-high debt in the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan risks slowing growth and destabilizing the global economy.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Raise Tariffs on South Korea to 25%
item.description: President Trump threatened to increase tariffs on South Korean exports, including cars, citing the country’s slow ratification of a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on Monday said he would raise tariffs on South Korea.

item.title: UK Seeks Trade With China Without Triggering Trump’s Fury
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer hopes to boost his country’s lagging economy with a trip to Beijing. But he must carefully navigate between two superpowers.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and David Pierson
item.media:credit: Stefan Rousseau/Pool, via Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain and Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, attending a meeting in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in 2024.

item.title: Home Sourdough Bakers Are Turning Their Hobbies Into Full-Time Jobs
item.description: Home bakers are finding devoted customer bases that allow them to stay home with family and still make a decent living — but they do have get up in the middle of the night.
item.dc:creator: Meghan McCarron
item.media:credit: Lissa Gotwals for The New York Times
item.media:description: Home sourdough bakers like Marcelle Malkin, who left a career in finance to start her operation, have found balance between work and family.

item.title: Social Media Giants Face Landmark Legal Tests on Child Safety
item.description: Starting this week, a series of trials will test a new legal strategy claiming that Meta, TikTok, Snap and YouTube caused personal injury through addictive products.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Matt Cardy/Getty Images
item.media:description: Jury selection is expected to start Tuesday for the first trial in a series of lawsuits that target social media companies with a strategy that had success against tobacco giants.

item.title: The Social Media Addiction Trials: What to Know
item.description: Landmark trials beginning this week will test a new legal strategy claiming that Meta, TikTok, Snap and YouTube caused personal injury through addictive products.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: David Gray/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The lawsuits will for the first time put social media companies on the spot for creating harmful products, exposing them to new kinds of liability.

item.title: Trump Briefed on Intelligence Saying Iran’s Government Is Weaker
item.description: Protests that erupted late last year shook elements of the Iranian government, according to the reports.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Vahid Salemi/Associated Press
item.media:description: A street in Tehran on Sunday. The reports signal that the Iranian government’s hold on power is at its weakest point since the shah was overthrown in the 1979 revolution.

item.title: Democrats Embrace a Shutdown Fight They Wanted to Avoid
item.description: After a second fatal shooting of a U.S. citizen in Minneapolis, Democrats say public opinion is on their side and they are willing to risk a backlash to counter what they see as police-state tactics.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents in Minneapolis after the shooting of a U.S. citizen on Saturday.

item.title: Court Affirms Ruling That Alina Habba Served Unlawfully as U.S. Attorney
item.description: The Justice Department lost a bid to challenge a decision that had found Ms. Habba was serving unlawfully as New Jersey’s top federal prosecutor.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich and Tracey Tully
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Alina Habba, a former personal lawyer to President Trump, is now a senior adviser to Attorney General Pam Bondi and oversees U.S. attorneys across the country.

item.title: Trump Administration Takes Another Stake in Rare Earth Sector
item.description: The administration announced a $1.6 billion deal with USA Rare Earth. The firm also does business with Cantor Fitzgerald, which is run by the sons of President Trump’s commerce secretary.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Liam Kennedy for The New York Times
item.media:description: “This investment ensures our supply chains are resilient and no longer reliant on foreign nations,” Howard Lutnick, the secretary of commerce, said of the deal.

item.title: NATO Chief Says Europe Is ‘Dreaming’ if It Thinks It Can Defend Itself Without U.S.
item.description: Mark Rutte, the secretary general of the alliance, told members of the European Parliament that President Trump was “doing a lot of good stuff.”
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Nicolas Tucat/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Secretary General Mark Rutte of NATO, right, at the European Parliament in Brussels on Monday.

item.title: A Year After DC Plane Crash, Concerns About Airport’s Safety Continue
item.description: The Federal Aviation Administration says it has reduced traffic in and out of the airport and designed safer routes. Crash victims’ families want more.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura for The New York Times

item.title: F.A.A. Rolls Out Agency Overhaul for Improving Air Safety
item.description: The announcement of a reorganization comes nearly a year after a midair collision killed 67 people and prompted a public outcry for enhancing the security of aviation travel.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bryan Bedford, the leader of the Federal Aviation Administration, during a hearing at the Capitol last month.

item.title: All-Night Concerts in War-Ravaged Myanmar
item.description: But the shows, which combine dance, drama and music, are also part of an effort by Myanmar’s military rulers to project a veneer of legitimacy.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Lauren DeCicca

item.title: The Time Has Come for the U.S. to Act in Iran
item.description: It is time for the U.S. to intervene militarily in Iran, at least to deter future killings of protesters.
item.dc:creator: Masih Alinejad
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: The War in Minnesota Is for Our Phones
item.description: We need to protect our right to carry cameras to document ICE’s violence.
item.dc:creator: Julia Angwin
item.media:credit: Associated Press, Getty Images, The New York Times, and Reuters

item.title: How Bad Are A.I. Delusions? We Asked People Treating Them.
item.description: Dozens of doctors and therapists said chatbots had led their patients to psychosis, isolation and unhealthy habits.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Valentino-DeVries and Kashmir Hill
item.media:credit: William DeShazer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Julia Sheffield, a psychologist at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville, is navigating how to treat problems caused or exacerbated by A.I. chatbots.

item.title: Chinese Pandas Leave Japanese Zoo
item.description: As Japan and China feud, an animal long used in Chinese diplomacy has been summoned back home.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Issei Kato/Reuters
item.media:description: Visitors taking last photos of Xiao Xiao at the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo on Sunday.

item.title: Thomas Fogarty, 91, Who Helped Revolutionize Vascular Surgery, Dies
item.description: Drawing on his love of fly-fishing, he developed a balloon catheter that removes blood clots from patients’ limbs in a minimally invasive way. It has saved millions of lives.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:credit: Jeff Zelevansky/Associated Press
item.media:description: Dr. Thomas J. Fogarty in 2000 on receiving the Lemelson-M.I.T. Prize for his work in developing medical technologies. He “single-handedly changed the face of cardiovascular surgery,” a colleague said.

item.title: Canada’s Marineland Whales Could Find New Homes in U.S.
item.description: Marineland, a closed aquatic park in Ontario, had threatened to euthanize its whales after the government denied an application to send them to China.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Daphné Lemelin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Beluga whales in November at the now-closed Arctic Cove exhibit at Marineland, in Niagara Falls, Canada.
